prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Statutory criteria for transfer—Convenience of parties and witnesses

para.paratext: The convenience of parties and witnesses is by its very nature a nebulous standard. The Panel has consistently taken a broad view of the question, and has sought to maximize the convenience of all the parties and witnesses, taken as a whole.[1] The Panel has rejected attempts to consider the convenience of individual parties and witnesses to the exclusion of others.[2] Judge Wisdom stated in a frequently cited passage from an early Panel decision:

Of course it is to the interest of each plaintiff to have all of the proceedings in his suit handled in his district. But the Panel must weigh the interests of all the plaintiffs and all the defendants, and must consider multiple litigation as a whole in the light of the purposes of the law.[3]

In another case, the Panel described the arguments of counsel, each seeking transfer of the cases under consideration to his or her home district, as “rather parochial.”[4] Even if the Panel doesn't point out that it is not persuaded by these parochial arguments, it is reasonably clear that they are not persuasive.

Although merely some enhancement of the convenience of parties and witnesses is sufficient to meet the requirement of the statute, the Panel has generally required that transfer offer some meaningful reduction in overall inconvenience before it will order transfer.[5] The Panel will not assume that the mere presence of common questions of fact will make transfer reduce the inconvenience of parties and witnesses. In an early case before the Panel, a concurring member stated:

To put it in other words, neither the convenience of witnesses and parties nor the just and efficient conduct of actions are served, ipso facto, by transfer just because there are common questions of fact in the civil actions involved.[6]

The consideration of convenience of the parties is a balancing of all the interests of all the parties. The Panel has refused to order transfer, despite convenience benefits to some defendants, where the transfer would impose inconvenience burdens on the plaintiffs.[7] The Panel can judge the convenience of the parties and witnesses for itself, but this factor may also drive the Panel's interest in the views of the parties on the subject of transfer,[8] and also selection of a transferee district if centralization is ordered.[9]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
